messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 64 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Sparse High Dimensional Expanders via Local Lifts

Paper Abstract: Abstract High dimensional expanders (HDXs) are a hypergraph generalization of expander graphs. They are extensively studied in the math and TCS communities due to their many applications. Like expander graphs, HDXs are especially interesting for applications when they are bounded degree, namely, if the number of edges adjacent to every vertex is bounded. However, only a handful of constructions are known to have this property, all of which rely on non-trivial algebraic techniques. In particular, no random or combinatorial construction of bounded degree high dimensional expanders is known. As a result, our understanding of these objects is limited. The degree of an iùëñi-face in an HDX is the number of (i+1)ùëñ1(i+1)-faces that contain it. In this work we construct complexes whose higher dimensional faces have bounded degree. This is done by giving an elementary and deterministic algorithm that takes as input a regular kùëòk-dimensional HDX XùëãX and outputs another regular kùëòk-dimensional HDX X^^ùëã\widehat{X} with twice as many vertices. While the degree of vertices in X^^ùëã\widehat{X} grows, the degree of the (k‚àí1)ùëò1(k-1)-faces in X^^ùëã\widehat{X} stays the same. As a result, we obtain a new ‚Äòalgebra-free‚Äô construction of HDXs whose (k‚àí1)ùëò1(k-1)-face degree is bounded. Our construction algorithm is based on a simple and natural generalization of the expander graph construction by Bilu and Linial [BL06], which build expander graphs using lifts coming from edge signings. Our construction is based on local lifts of high dimensional expanders, where a local lift is a new complex whose top-level links are lifts of the links of the original complex. We demonstrate that a local lift of an HDX is also an HDX in many cases. In addition, combining local lifts with existing bounded degree constructions creates new families of bounded degree HDXs with significantly different links than before. We use this technique to construct bounded degree high dimensional expanders with links that have arbitrarily large diameters.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 64 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 64"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "NLTS Hamiltonians from good quantum codes",
        "The spectrum of random lifts",
        "Small Lifts of Expander Graphs are Expanding",
        "Random graph coverings I: General theory and graph connectivity",
        "Random lifts of graphs",
        "Log-concave polynomials II: high-dimensional walks and an FPRAS for counting bases of a matroid",
        "The probabilistic method",
        "Ramanujan type buildings",
        "Locally 4-by-4 grid graphs",
        "On graphs with a constant link, II",
        "Lifts, Discrepancy and Nearly Optimal Spectral Gap",
        "Constant Degree Direct Product Testers with Small Soundness",
        "Characterizing Direct Product Testing via Coboundary Expansion",
        "A new proof of Friedman‚Äôs second eigenvalue theorem and its extension to random lifts",
        "Stability of Homomorphisms, Coverings and Cocycles II: Examples, Applications and Open problems",
        "Expander Graphs ‚Äî Both Local and Global",
        "Hypergraph expanders from Cayley graphs",
        "Ramanujan geometries of type An",
        "Hypergraph expanders of all uniformities from Cayley graphs",
        "Agreement theorems for high dimensional expanders in the small soundness regime: the role of covers",
        "Low Acceptance Agreement Tests via Bounded-Degree Symplectic HDXs",
        "New High Dimensional Expanders from Covers",
        "Locally testable codes with constant rate, distance, and locality",
        "The PCP theorem by gap amplification",
        "High dimensional expanders imply agreement expanders",
        "New Codes on High Dimensional Expanders",
        "Problems and results on 3-chromatic hypergraphs and some related questions, in ‚ÄúInfinite and Finite Sets‚Äù(A. Hajnal et al., Eds.)",
        "Hyper-regular graphs and high dimensional expanders",
        "Splitting an expander graph",
        "Overlap properties of geometric expanders",
        "A proof of Alon‚Äôs second eigenvalue conjecture and related problems",
        "List Agreement Expansion from Coboundary Expansion",
        "No Where to Go But High: A Perspective on High Dimensional Expanders",
        "A sample of samplers: A computational perspective on sampling",
        "Improved Product-Based High-Dimensional Expanders",
        "From Grassmannian to Simplicial High-Dimensional Expanders",
        "Singularities, Expanders and Topology of Maps. Part 2: from Combinatorics to Topology Via Algebraic Isoperimetry",
        "Expander graphs and their applications",
        "The existence of designs",
        "High dimensional expanders and property testing",
        "The art of computer programming. Vol. 1: Fundamental algorithms.",
        "Construction of new local spectral high dimensional expanders",
        "Ramanujan hypergraphs",
        "Local and Global Expansion in Random Geometric Graphs",
        "Random Steiner systems and bounded degree coboundary expanders of every dimension",
        "Homological Connectivity Of Random 2-Complexes",
        "High-Dimensional Expanders from Expanders",
        "Ramanujan graphs",
        "Explicit constructions of Ramanujan complexes of type Ad~~subscriptùê¥ùëë\\tilde{A_{d}}",
        "Ramanujan complexes of type Ad~~subscriptùê¥ùëë\\tilde{A_{d}}",
        "High dimensional expanders",
        "Locally grid graphs: classification and Tutte uniqueness",
        "Explicit constructions of expanders",
        "Interlacing families I: Bipartite Ramanujan graphs of all degrees",
        "A constructive proof of the general Lov√°sz local lemma",
        "Homological connectivity of random k-dimensional complexes",
        "The spectrum of random k-lifts of large graphs (with possibly large k)",
        "High-Dimensional Expanders from Chevalley Groups",
        "Asymptotically good Quantum and locally testable classical LDPC codes",
        "Undirected connectivity in log-space",
        "Entropy waves, the zig-zag graph product, and new constant-degree expanders",
        "Expander codes",
        "Covers of simplicial complexes and applications to geometry",
        "Explicit, almost optimal, epsilon-balanced codes"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 64 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Sparse High Dimensional Expanders via Local Lifts, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
